summary.seg: This Greek manuscript is composed of two separate parts, each with independent foliation, often referred to in the literature by two internal classmarks: Nn.3.16.1, as recorded on ff. 2r and 145v of Part I, and Nn.3.16.2 on f. 1r of Part II.

Nn.3.16.1 contains two comedies by the Athenian writer Aristophanes (b. c. 446, d. 385 BCE): Plutus (known also as Wealth) and Nubes (known also as Clouds), along with scholia by the Byzantine grammarians Thomas Magistros and Demetrius Triclinius (13th-14th century). The Greek text is cited in the editions of Aristophanes as Ct4 or Cant. 4, and it was collated by P. Dobree in the 19th century ( Ricardi Porsoni notae in Aristophanem, Cambridge 1820).

Nn.3.16.2 contains the didactic poem Opera et dies (Works and days) by the poet Hesiod, with the scholia by the Byzantine grammarian Manuel Moschopoulus (13th-14th century), author of the introduction to the poem on f. 1r. The manuscript was collated by F.A. Paley (The epics of Hesiod, Cambridge 1861).

foliation.p: Two foliation schemes are present, both restarting at the beginning of Part II. 19th-century foliations in pencil in Arabic numerals in the top right-hand corner, recto. Folio number 1 of Part I was assigned to a leaf no longer present in the volume, according to the interpretation of the manuscript's collation (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).
Previous foliations not original to the manuscript, in pencil in Greek numerals in the lower margin of rectos.

collation.p: Nn.3.16.1 consists of 18 quires and a single folio, Nn.3.16.2 of 4 quires: 18-1, 2-188, 191 | 20-228, 2310.
Henry Bradshaw Bradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886 added the bifolium signatures and a note on collation on f. [v] recto, and notes throughout the manuscript on the lost and cancelled folios.

binding.p: Bound with pale brown full skin covering over millboards. There is decorative tooling on boards, spine and on the board edge. The title (Aristophan Plutus Nubes Hesiodi Opera et Dies) is tooled in gold on the spine. Marbled paper is used as pastedowns with blank leaves.

provenance.p: The manuscript, in all likelihood in both its parts, belonged to the Monastery of Dionysiou on Mount Athos: on Nn.3.16.1, f. 3v an ownership inscription of the Monastery (κτῆμα μονῆς τοῦ κυρίου Διονυσίου) is repeated three times by a later hand, probabily the same one that added the foliation in Greek numerals. The manuscript later belonged to the collection of the physician Richard Mead Mead, Richard, 1673-1754 (b. 1673, d. 1754), and eventually entered into the library of Anthony Askew Askew, Anthony, 1722-1774 (b. 1722, d. 1774), physician and book collector.

history.acquisition: After Askew's death, the manuscripts were sold by G. Leigh and J. Sotheby in the auction of his library in 1785 (Nn.3.16 Lot. n. 554), and were eventually bought by Richard Farmer for Cambridge University Library. The University of Cambridge general bookplate (engraved by William Jackson in 1706-1707) was added on inside front board.

recordHist.source: Description (2019) draws on A catalogue of the Manuscripts preserved in the Library of the University of Cambridge, vol. 4, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1861, p. 486-487.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Thoman Life of Aristophanes (Vita XXXIII 1 Koster 1975, Scholia in Aristophanem I.1.a)
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Ἀριστοφάνης ὁ κωμωδοποιὸς γένος μὲν ἦν ἀθηναῖος· πατρὸς δὲ φιλίππου τὸν δὲ δῆμον κυδαθηναῖος
msItem.explicit: f. 2v ἀποθανόντα δὲ οὕτω Πλάτων· ἐτίμησεν ἐν ἡρωελεγείω· αἱ χάριτες τέμενος ὅπερ οὐχὶ πεσεῖται, ζητοῦσαι ψυχὴν εὗρον ἀριστοφάνους
msItem.note: on the final epigram, cf. Greek Anthology Appendix III 33 and DBBE type 5362

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on Plutus
Thoman Argumentum (ed. Chantry 1996, Scholia in Aristophanem III.4.b)
msItem.incipit: f. 2v βουλόμενος ἀριστοφάνης σκῶψαι ἀθηναίους ἀδικία καὶ συκοφαντία καὶ τοῖς τοιούτοις συνόντας
msItem.explicit: f. 3r οὐκ αὐτοὶ μόνον ἀλλὰ καὶ ὅσοι βίου χρηστοῦ πρόσθεν ἀντεχόμενοι πένητες ἦσαν. ἐπιγέγραπται δὲ καὶ τὸ δράμα, πλοῦτος ἀριστοφάνους
msItem.note: followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Aristophanes
msItem.title: Plutus
Wealth
msItem.incipit: f. 4r Ὡς ἀργαλέον πρᾶγμ’ ἐστίν ὦ ζεῦ καὶ θεοί δοῦλον γενέσθαι παραφρονοῦντος δεσπότου
msItem.explicit: f. 68v οὐκ ἔτι τοίνυν γ’ εἰκὸς μένειν οὐδ’ ἡμᾶς ἀλλ’ ἀναχωρεῖν εἰς τοὔπισθεν· δεῖ γὰρ κατόπιν τούτοις ἄδοντας ἕπεσθαι
msItem.note: extensive scholia and interlinear glosses by different hand in red and faded black ink accompany the text; f. 8v left blank without loss of text

msItem.author: Thomas, Magistros, active 1310-1327
msItem.title: Hypothesis on Nubes
Thoman Argumentum Nubium (Arg. Ia Koster 1974, Scholia in Aristophanem I.3.2)
msItem.incipit: f. 69r Ἄνυτος καὶ Μέλητος Σωκράτει τῶ Σωφρονίσκου βασκήναντες, καὶ αὐτὸν μὴ δυνάμενοι βλάψαι, ἀργύριον ἱκανὸν ἀριστοφάνει δεδώκασιν
msItem.explicit: f. 69v συνίσταται δὲ τὸ δράμα ἐκ χοροῦ νεφελῶν· ἔχει δὲ κατηγορίαν τοῦ σωκράτους· ὅτι τοὺς συνήθεις θεοὺς ἀφεὶς, καινὰ ἐνόμιζε δαιμόνια· ἀέρα· νεφέλας· καὶ τὰ τοιαῦτα
msItem.note: followed by the list of characters of the play

msItem.author: Aristophanes
msItem.title: Nubes
Clouds
msItem.explicit: f. 145v ἡγεῖσθ’ ἔξω κεχόρευται γὰρ μετρίως τό γε τήμερον ἡμῖν
msItem.finalRubric: f. 145v τὸ τέρμ᾽ ὧδ᾽ ἐστὶ δράματος τοῦ δευτέρου
msItem.note: f. 143v: lines 1438-1468 omitted (as noted by H. Bradshaw)
extensive scholia and interlinear glosses by different hand in red and faded black ink accompany the text.

support.material: ff. 2r-145v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark not visible.

signatures.p: A bifolium signature (Latin letters for quires, followed by Arabic numerals for bifolios) in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos of the first four folios, followed by a cross on the fifth, was added by Henry Bradshaw: a-i, k-t.

condition.p: In fair condition; leaves are yellow with age. There are extensive stains and wormholes, ff. 2-8 are more damaged than the rest of the volume. Small tears have been repaired with glued paper that sometimes covers part of the text of the scholia. A small tear at f. 41 near the gutter is unrepaired. The lower outer corner of f. 2 was lost, and with it about a third of the text.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 4r-145v: 130 80
Scholia that accompany the main texts have a very variable number of lines per page, and are arranged in a orderly manner.

handNote.p: The main text is written in a mixed minuscule in an upright slanting slightly to the right, in dark brown ink. There is only moderate variation in letter size.
Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are nearly absent. Breathings are curved and mute iota is not used.

The small majuscules beta, gamma, eta, lambda phi are present. Beta has sometimes a bilobated shape, theta is both in open and round form, epsilon is both regular minuscule and rarely lunate and enlarged. The sigma telikon is present along with regular shape. Epsilon in ligature is deformed.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.

additions.p: Ownership notes of the Monastery of Dionysiou (Mount Athos) have been added on f. f. 3v: κτῆμα μονῆς τοῦ κυρίου Διονυσίου.

origin.p: The characteristics of the script suggest that it was produced in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.author: Moschopoulos, Manuel, approximately 1265?
msItem.title: Introduction to Hesiod's Works and days
msItem.incipit: f. 1r ἰστέον ὅτι πάντα οἱ ἕλληνες, ἃ δύναμιν ἔχοντα ἑώρων, οὐκ ἄνευ ἐπιστασίας
msItem.explicit: f. 1r ἵνα μὴ τῆς τοῦ διὸς ὀργῆς πειραθῆ τὴν πλεονεξίαν ὁρῶντος αὐτοῦ
msItem.note: f. 1v bears scholia by Moschopoulus on lines 1-10

msItem.author: Hesiod
msItem.title: Opera et dies
Works and days
msItem.rubric: f. 2r ἡσιόδου ἔργα καὶ ἡμέραι (nearly faded, on the edge of the upper margin)
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Μοῦσαι πιερίηθεν ἀειδῇσι κλείουσαι δεῦτε δὴ ἐννέπετε σφέτερον πατέρ’ ὑμνείουσαι
msItem.explicit: f. 34r εἰδὼς, ἐργάζηται ἀναίτιος ἀθανάτοισιν· ὄρνιθας κρίνων· καὶ ὑπερβασίας ἀλεείνων
msItem.finalRubric: f. 34r τέλος τῶν ἔργων καὶ ἡμερῶν ἡσιόδου
msItem.note: extensive interlinear glosses in red ink and some scholia in brown ink accompany the text

support.material: ff. 1r-34v Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Shield with pale partially visible on ff. 5, 9, 19 ( 25 30 ) near the gutter.

signatures.p: There is a bifolium signature (Latin letters for quires and Arabic numerals for bifolios) by Henry Bradshaw in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos: a-d.

condition.p: In good condition. Leaves are yellow with age and stains are rare.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 2r-34r: 165 85
Scholia and prefatory materials that accompany the main texts have a very variable number of lines per page, and are arranged in a orderly manner.

handNote.p: The main texts are written in a mixed minuscule in an upright, scribal hand, in brown ink script.

There is not a marked variation in letter size. Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings are rare, and usually appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are curved and mute iota is not used.

The small majuscules beta, gamma, eta, kappa and phi are present. Gamma and tau are oftenly high. The majuscule beta has a curled bilobate shape, and epsilon is both regular minuscule and lunate. The sigma telikon is not present. Omega is always closed.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper point, lower comma and full stop.

decoNote.p: The beginning of the text on f. 2r is preceded by rectangular headpieces in brown ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: An ornated initial, outlined in red ink on f. 2r.

origin.p: The characteristics of the script and the watermarks suggest that it was produced in the late 15th century.
